subNodes.conversationText: The woodcutter’s son led the young witch to the tree and lay his axe in the crimson grass. There was a crook in the roots, almost like a seat, and the boy, apparently accustomed to doing so, sat in it and leaned his head against the trunk.
<FirstName> sat in the crook of the tree the way <he/she>’d seen the woodcutter’s son do. The sea of grass in the meadow that grew around it rippled. The sky was gray, the air heavy and fragrant.

The woodcutter’s son led the young witch to the tree and lay his axe in the crimson grass. There was a crook in the roots, almost like a seat, and the boy, apparently accustomed to doing so, sat in it and leaned his head against the trunk.
“Sometimes, I come here and sleep when my work is done. The tree changes your dreams. It makes them stranger. That’s why the grass is red.”
"So you sleep here to have strange dreams?"
"Good? I don't know. They're strange. I can't really remember them. But I do remember the name Malkin."
"That's how I know the name. I've heard it in the dreams. I thought he was just a person in my dreams, but maybe he comes here sometimes. Maybe he plants his dreams in the grass."
"They're hard to describe. I know the feeling, but..." He trailed off.
"That's how I know the name. I've heard it in the dreams. I thought he was just a person in my dreams, but maybe he comes here sometimes. Maybe he plants his dreams in the grass."
"I'm pretty sure he's real. The kami showed me."
He had taken a long branch from the bundle of sticks he always had with him and was whittling it. The young witch watched him. He soon took out a goose feather and began trimming it.
<FirstName> took out the arrow that killed Nnenne. "Did you make this?"
"No. My father told me I was too young for a bow."
"He let you have a hatchet but not a bow?"
"That's exactly what I said to him."
<FirstName> took out the arrow that killed Nnenne. "Did you make this?"
<FirstName> took out the arrow that killed Nnenne. "Did you make this?"
<FirstName> took out the arrow that killed Nnenne. "Did you make this?"
The boy stopped what he was doing and took the arrow. The blood didn't alarm him. He touched the point with the tip of his finger then ran his hand over the fletching.

"Yes," he said, handing it back to the young witch. "There are three hunters who live in the woods. I probably sold it to one of them." So much for Eldest Lady's notion that the one hunter who shot with goose-fletched was Nnenne's killer, thought to self. One of them might be Nnenne's killer, but they couldn't all be Nnenne's killer.
<He/She> now doubted that the blood <he/she> had was that of a guilty man. Why had the witches given <him/her> this terrible errand? What did it have to do with Malkin?
Why had the witches given <him/her> this terrible errand? What did it have to do with Malkin?

"You know more now than you once knew," said a familiar voice inside <FirstName>'s head.
                                                                               "A third
Thing left to know our sibling on the mountain
Keeps for you."

The boy packed his things away and got up.

"It's not as peaceful here with you standing around asking questions. I'm going back home."

He went back the way they'd come. Pharaoh, who'd kept his distance from the boy, flew down to a low branch in the tree and cawed loudly after him.

actions.a_parameter_1:
NEW JOURNAL ENTRY
The Three Kami: The Third Kami

The woodcutter's son led the young witch to a tree where he had dreamed about Malkin, but he couldn't tell the witch anything about Malkin himself. The young witch also learned that the boy made the arrow that killed Nnenne and that all the hunters in the woods used his arrows. After their conversation, the spirits said to look for the third kami to learn more.

"You know more now than you once knew," said a familiar voice inside <FirstName>'s head.
                                                                             "A third
Thing left to know our sibling in the cavern
Keeps for you."

"You know more now than you once knew," said a familiar voice inside <FirstName>'s head.
                                                                          "A third
Thing left to know our sibling in the meadow
Keeps for you."

"Yes," he said, handing it back to the young witch. "There are three hunters who live in the woods. I probably sold it to one of them."

The young witch thought back to the scene in Sudder's cabin and shook <his/her> head.
Why had the witches given <him/her> this terrible errand? What did it have to do with Malkin?

"Yes," he said, handing it back to the young witch. "There are three hunters who live in the woods. I probably sold it to one of them."

The young witch thought back to the hunter who had dreamed about his own death and shook <his/her> head.
Why had the witches given <him/her> this terrible errand? What did it have to do with Malkin?

"Yes," he said, handing it back to the young witch. "There are three hunters who live in the woods. I probably sold it to one of them."

The young witch thought back to the scene in Sudder's cabin and to Wencel, the hunter who had dreamed about his own death. <He/She> shook <his/her> head.
Why had the witches given <him/her> this terrible errand? What did it have to do with Malkin?
"It looks like you're making an arrow."
<FirstName> took out the arrow that killed Nnenne. "Did you make this?"
<FirstName> took out the arrow that killed Nnenne. "Did you make this?"
<FirstName> studied the tree, crimson grass, and blue flowers.

It didn't take a witch to see that the place was enchanted. It was late summer, but the tree looked like it had budded not long. Still, many of the leaves had fallen off. <He/She> didn't know what kind it was -- nor did <he/she> recognize the sedge or flowers that grew around it.
"Malkin is a witch like me. His witchcraft draws you here."
The boy nodded but didn't seem interested.
"The kami showed me Malkin. He's real."
"Malkin is a witch like me. His witchcraft draws you here."
<FirstName> sat in the crook of the tree the way <he/she>’d seen the woodcutter’s son do. The sea of grass in the meadow that grew around it rippled. The sky was gray, the air heavy and fragrant.
A light breeze spread through the August air like milk in bitter tea. The place <he/she> sat seemed to welcome his body, and <he/she> soon fell asleep.

Then <he/she> dreamed. <He/She> looked out a window over the rooftops and spires of a grand city. Was it Wanrho? Jhilyong? Awadabyss? It was a place <FirstName> had never been, but its size told <him/her> <he/she> must have heard of it.
Beside stood Malkin. shuddered. This wasn't like the kami's visions -- Malkin was there, in dream, and could see the young witch. He turned to . His gaze was thrilling.
"Awadabyss," said Malkin, gesturing out the window.

"That tower, those spires -- that's the university. And that latticework of streets and stalls with the big circle in the middle -- those are the markets at the Plaza of the Kingfisher. There's no better place to eat in the world -- infinite variety."
"And that?" asked <FirstName>, pointing to something that looked like a temple.

Malkin frowned.

"I don't remember it. How did they make it, and from what? Where did they dig up that smooth, black stone? They're sacrificing people inside."
He turned from the view and looked hard at <FirstName> again. "Wait. Who are you?"
"I have no friends now," he laughed. "So that's not right. Not a friend, but I do know you. I don't know how, but I do."

The sun had been high as they looked out over Awadabyss, but now it was night. 

"It's late. I'll come to know you better. Follow me," he said.

He led <FirstName> down three corridors and through three arches. The first was ancient and hewn from stone, and a bed lay beyond it. The second arch was made of an alloy of bronze, and another bed lay beyond that. The third arch was made of freshly carved wood. There was nothing on the other side.
"My bed!" Malkin cried. "Where is my bed?"
Bloody grass grew up through the cracks in the stone floor. Blue flowers sprang up too.
"Wait...You're already sleeping in my bed, aren't you?" said Malkin.
The young witch admitted it was true. <He/She> was ashamed.
<FirstName> woke up. <He/She> stood and walked away from the tree, wondering what the dream meant.
"Yes, yes, it's true!" said the young witch scornfully.
"It's not true. The earth is the biggest bed," said <FirstName>.
"Oh? I don't remember. I do know you, but I don't know how. I don't think it was like that, but I could be wrong."
"I know that," said, "just as you know that I'm a witch too. But how do I know you?"
He bristled. "Kin? What kin? No -- that's not it. I do know you, but I don't know how."
"And that?" asked <FirstName>, pointing to a gleaming villa on a hill.
Malkin laughed, blushing a little. "I've spent many nights there. It's beautiful, but nothing like the beauty of someone who lives there. Lived there, I should say."
"And that?" asked <FirstName>, pointing to the distant sea.
"The ocean! The ocean, of course. The greatest ocean by far, Orooc." He caught himself. "Well, the greatest ocean in this world."

<He/She> watched two birds flying together over the woods, mere specks beyond the grass. <He/She> studied the odd blue flowers and idly tore some of the blood-colored grass, half-expecting it to bleed. It didn't.
